While those breeds did traditionally work (e.g. guarding), today those specific dogs from he Working Dog Group may or may not perform those jobs they were meant for years back.

Today most of the western people take a dog solely to be a pet, ignoring the genetics of the breed.

Fortunately today we do have institutions (police, military, order police, etc) and civilian people that need a dog to do one or more jobs.

These dogs have natural talents that are carefully honed with intensive training. Working dogs are trained to help others and they love the work, because it is still in their DNA.

Service Dogs

These are special trained dogs that will assist people with all kinds of disabilities, providing vital and often lifesaving support to those who need it most.

Types of Service Dogs

  • Guide Dogs
  • Mobility Assistance Dogs
  • Seizure Alert and Response Dogs
  • Hearing Dogs
  • Diabetic Alert Dogs
  • Allergy Detection Dogs
  • Autism Support Dogs
  • Psychiatric Service Dogs

Check out my blog “8 Types of Service Dogs And What There Jobs Are” for detailed information about service dogs.

Therapy Dogs

Unfortunately these dogs are not recognized as service dogs, and they do not enjoy the same rights as a service dogs has.

Nonetheless, these dogs perform an important job as well: provide affection, comfort and love to people.

These people can be the handler itself or children, or elderly.

There have been numerous reports that these dogs help many psychological health issues such as anxiety, depression, social skills, and simply improving the moods of the patient.

Dogs of any breed, size, or age can become therapy dogs but they need very good socialization, and training.

Search and Rescue Dogs

These dogs have an exceptional senses of smell and hearing. The SAR Dogs serve in many different fields: wilderness tracking, natural disaster search, mass casualty events, avalanche rescue, missing persons and cadaver location.

Types of Search and Rescue Dogs

  • Air-scenting Dogs
  • Trailing Dogs
  • Detection Dogs

Detection dogs have exceptional sense of smell. A detection dog is trained to sniff out a particular substance or a group of substances, his training motivation being positive reinforcement.

Detection dogs are used in law enforcement, wildlife biology, and health care.

The Detection Dog is trained to use its senses to detect substances such as explosives, illegal drugs, wildlife scat, currency, blood, human remains, contraband, cancer, abnormal blood sugar levels, certain types of insects (e.g. bed bugs), mold, termites, truffles, and so much more.

Police Dogs or The K-9 Unit

The K-9 unit is trained to assist law enforcement in the line of duty. These dogs are used for chasing and apprehending criminal suspects.

In many cases a Police Dog is assigned to one handler for many years or even until retirement and after that most of the times the police officers adopts the retired dog.

In many countries, the intentional injuring or killing of a police dog is a criminal offence.

The most commonly used breeds are the German Shepherd, Belgian Malinois, Dutch Shepherd.

Military Working Dogs or The K-9 Unit

Military Dogs are trained to assist soldiers in the line of duty. These dogs are used for intimidation, guarding, sentries, scouts, apprehending suspects, attack if the handler gives the command or if the handler himself is injured.

All MWDs in use today are paired with a single individual after their training.

This person is called a handler.

While a handler usually won’t stay with one dog for the length of either’s career, usually a handler will stay partnered with a dog for at least a year, and sometimes much longer.

The latest canine tactical vests are outfitted with cameras and durable microphones that allow dogs to relay audio and visual information to their handlers.

The most commonly used breeds are the German Shepherd, Belgian Malinois, Dutch Shepherd.

Herding Dogs

Herding Dogs were bred to help ranchers move their livestock.

In addition to herding, a lot of these breeds are naturally good protectors as well, making them good guard dogs and oftentimes reserved around strangers.

Who doesn’t know Lassie the movie star Collie?

Bird Dogs

Comprised of several types of dogs — pointers (German shorthair), retrievers (Golden or Labrador), setters (English, Irish), flushers (Cocker Spaniel, Springer Spaniel), and water dogs (Poodle, Portuguese Water Dog).

These breeds were developed to help bird hunters find, flush out and retrieve their game.

Guard Dogs

Guardian breeds, like Giant Schnauzers, Tibetan Mastiffs, Doberman Pinschers, Cane Corso, are oftentimes seen as aggressive and untrustworthy because they take their home guarding role very serious.

Sight Dogs

Bred for helping hunters track prey by sight, breeds like the Greyhound, Saluki, and the Irish Wolfhound, have an awesome sight and extremely fast.

Terriers

Often referred to as “terror terriers”, is one of the most notorious dog group.

They were bred to be ostentatious hunters of game.

Most known are the American Staffordshire Terrier, the infamous Jack Russell and the perky West Highland Terrier.
